places.title: Lalbagh Fort
places.description: Lalbagh Fort (also Fort Aurangabad) is an incomplete 17th-century Mughal fort complex that stands before the Buriganga River in the southwestern part of Dhaka, Bangladesh. The construction was started in 1678 AD by Mughal Subahdar Muhammad Azam Shah who was the son of Emperor Aurangzeb and later emperor himself. His successor, Shaista Khan, did not continue the work, though he stayed in Dhaka up to 1688.

places.title: Ahsan Manzil
places.description: The Pink Palace, a major historical and architectural landmark in Dhaka. Ahsan Manzil (Ahsan Monjil) was the official residential palace and seat of the Nawab of Dhaka. The building is situated at Kumartoli along the banks of the Buriganga River in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Construction was started in 1859 and was completed in 1872. It was constructed in the Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture. It has been designated as a national museum.

places.title: Jatiyo Sangsad Bhaban
places.description: An iconic modern architectural marvel and the seat of the national parliament of Bangladesh. Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban or National Parliament Building, (Bengali: জাতীয় সংসদ ভবন Jatiyô Sôngsôd Bhôbôn) is the house of the Parliament of Bangladesh, located at Sher-e-Bangla Nagar in the Bangladeshi capital of Dhaka. Designed while the country was still part of Pakistan by architect Louis Kahn, the complex is one of the largest legislative complexes in the world, covering 200 acres.

places.title: Dhakeshwari Temple
places.description: A Hindu temple in Dhaka, dedicated to the goddess Dhakeshwari.

places.title: National Museum of Bangladesh
places.description: Dhakeshwari National Temple (Bengali: ঢাকেশ্বরী জাতীয় মন্দির, romanized: Ðhakeshshori Jatio Mondir) is a Hindu temple in Dhaka, Bangladesh. It is state-owned, giving it the distinction of being Bangladesh's 'National Temple'. The name 'Dhakeshwari' 'Goddess of Dhaka'. Since the destruction of Ramna Kali Mandir in 1971 by the Pakistan Army during the Bangladesh Liberation War, the Dhakeshwari Temple has assumed status as the most important Hindu place of worship in Bangladesh.[1] It is also the largest Hindu temple in Bangladesh.[2] This temple is part of the famous Shakti Peethas in Indian Subcontinent. Here the gem of Sati's crown had fallen.

places.title: Dhanmondi Lake
places.description: Dhanmondi Lake is a prominent artificial lake located in the Dhanmondi residential area of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh. Created in the 1950s, the lake spans over an area of approximately 40 acres and serves as a popular recreational spot for locals. Surrounded by a picturesque landscape, the lake offers a tranquil environment where visitors can enjoy boat rides, picnics, and leisurely strolls along its scenic shores. The surrounding Dhanmondi area is known for its vibrant community and various amenities, making Dhanmondi Lake a popular destination for residents and tourists seeking a peaceful escape in the heart of Dhaka.

places.title: Jatio Shahid Minar
places.description: A monument built to commemorate the martyrs of the Bengali Language Movement. Jatio Shahid Minar, also known as the National Martyrs' Monument, is a significant landmark located in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Erected to commemorate the language martyrs who sacrificed their lives during the Language Movement of 1952, the monument stands at the intersection of Dhaka Medical College and University of Dhaka. The Language Movement was a key event in Bangladesh's history, advocating for the recognition of Bengali as the official language

places.title: Panam City
places.description: Panam City, or Panam Nagar, located in Sonargaon near Dhaka, Bangladesh, is a historic city known for its well-preserved colonial architecture that reflects Mughal and European influences. Once a thriving trading hub, it now stands as an archaeological site, offering visitors a glimpse into its rich past through dilapidated yet captivating structures. The unique blend of architectural styles and the city's historical significance make it a notable attraction for tourists and history enthusiasts.

places.title: Bangladesh National Zoo
places.description: The Bangladesh National Zoo, located in Dhaka, is a popular wildlife attraction. Established in 1974, the zoo covers a significant area and houses a diverse collection of animals, including native and exotic species. Visitors can explore various exhibits featuring mammals, birds, and reptiles. The zoo aims to promote conservation awareness and education while providing an enjoyable experience for visitors of all ages. It serves as a hub for biodiversity conservation efforts and offers a recreational space for families and nature enthusiasts in the capital city.
